section.text: Hey good morning everyone, so a couple of questions here more on the demand order side of things. First, on the order side, flattish orders against really tough multi year stacked comps here. It seems like a good outcome sequentially lower -- when I think about those order numbers, is there anything in there from a weakening perspective we should think about? And then -- how much of that sequential change is seasonality or just a normal air pocket that develops as lead times start normalizing to kind of historically normal levels?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Mike Halloran", "section_number": 1, "uuid": "e07c32ad-61ce-448a-b0f8-c247aff9a553", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Robert W. Baird"}

section.text: Yes. I mean, you hit a lot of the elements there. I mean, there's a piece of this that we always suspected was going to be there as we start to come off of incredibly high backlog positions, especially for a short cycle quick lead time business like ourselves. So there's a piece of it that no doubt will be that, and we'll keep an eye on the rate of travel of it as it runs out. There is some summer -- kind of summer month seasonality that's in there as well. I would say from a categorical softness standpoint, probably the one area we'd point to that covers a lot of IDEX businesses would be just some general softening on the European front, which probably isn't too surprising.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Eric Ashleman", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "a89f83f8-a397-47f5-8b4a-f4d2f0681802", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and President at IDEX"}

section.text: And then I'm sure we'll talk later here about projects, large projects and things of that nature. That's an interesting story. I mean, they were beginning of this whole recovery. I mean there was a lot of caution on people's parts sort of held them back. I think in the middle part or a lot of the duration, honestly, there was just not enough time and energy to get at it or resources. And now you're kind of seeing that tilt back probably it is more of a cautionary tone again -- we've got a few things that have moved out and placed themselves decisions into Q1 of next year, things of that nature as well. So few things that we can point to some things that are sort of normal based on where we are from a backlog position in time of the year. But underneath and around all of that, really, really strong support across the board.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Eric Ashleman", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "a89f83f8-a397-47f5-8b4a-f4d2f0681802", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and President at IDEX"}

section.text: Thanks, super helpful. And in the prepared remarks, you talked about the ability for IDEX to manage with whatever kind of environment during your way in 2023 and certainly, your track record supports that pretty aggressively. What is the base case that you guys are thinking about it today as we move into next year? Obviously, we've talked a lot about the need and the opportunity for a strong industrial cycle. It doesn't mean you can't get some weakness as we move into next year. So as you look through your pretty varied end markets going into next year, how are you thinking about that setup? And what's the opportunity set for growth.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Mike Halloran", "section_number": 3, "uuid": "05a71d52-beec-4354-b8a6-69bd3dff8eaa", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Robert W. Baird"}

section.text: Yes. Well, look, I think as I said in the prepared remarks, you could see a few paths that would run out here. I mean one that's more positive, something that's short-term and kind of a short-term pullback and then obviously, maybe something with a catalyst that's more negative that none of us can imagine. I just always come back when we talk about that in the company, I mean, we literally scenario play every one of those. We understand kind of what's variable, what's not variable across all our businesses. we always go back to the top growth that's in the company, almost all of which we can kind of see traveling across the duration here, we factor that in as well.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Eric Ashleman", "section_number": 4, "uuid": "e7f81d70-d37e-43f7-b118-5c677d600707", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and President at IDEX"}

section.text: We certainly learned a lot like every company about how low you can take discretionary spend in many ways, lower than we would have thought possible before. We know where that floor is and kind of how we would stack that against any of those scenarios. We've talked for a while on the headcount side, we'd be careful. Talent is hard to get. I mean, we're not really at a flush position there anyways. We're actually still pretty lean -- and we'd be very careful there. And then honestly, we would rotate towards the strong, and we go pretty lean on areas that are weaker. And so I want to be too predictive here because I think it's still pretty variable in our minds, but our approach to each one of those path is not. We actually know exactly what that is.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Eric Ashleman", "section_number": 4, "uuid": "e7f81d70-d37e-43f7-b118-5c677d600707", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and President at IDEX"}

section.text: Thanks for that, really appreciate it.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Mike Halloran", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "51d70ca0-5336-470a-bf93-5709a03ece86", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Robert W. Baird"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Eric Ashleman", "section_number": 6, "uuid": "5c14fa4e-af18-44c5-b604-98fa7b0724e8", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and President at IDEX"}

section.text: Good morning, everyone. I wanted to just with some price/cost discussion. You guys have said that price/cost has been dilutive to margins in 2022 -- is that something you target recapturing in 2023 as we've started to see costs moderate. Do you believe you can recapture that margin that was lost in 2022 to price/cost?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Nathan Jones", "section_number": 8, "uuid": "9e5462f4-0bfc-43e2-99c7-30ad4be19e72", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Stifel"}

section.text: Yes. No, definitely. As you said in the prepared remarks, we're back to historical levels here in the third quarter as we continue to ramp our price capture -- inflation hasn't gone down, but it's moderated a bit. So as we look forward to the stickiness of the price that we implemented here as we progress through 2022, that's sticking in 2023, optimistic about our ability to keep above our historical levels.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "William Grogan", "section_number": 9, "uuid": "6b4134d5-163d-4af6-a24e-d3b10a3a1474", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at IDEX"}

section.text: Okay. And maybe you could just talk a little bit about some of the order cadence in your shortest cycle businesses. I know you guys have a few businesses that tend to be canaries in the coal mine. I think you said BAND-IT still remains pretty strong. But any commentary you can give us on those businesses that you consider to be leading indicators of the order cadence there?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Nathan Jones", "section_number": 10, "uuid": "ab470b28-e961-4076-991e-8b7a79379a0e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Stifel"}

section.text: Yes. They're still really strong. I mean they have held steady. In many places, -- and as four or five of them, we've done a really nice job on putting some strategic inventory together. Our natural ability to replenish fast has allowed us to go capture some share and some orders and then turn them and converted them to sales pretty quick on top of it. So no real pressure signs coming from that very short cycle stuff that we always talk about. We look at that constantly. That's holding up. There's still an awful lot of demand for it, a lot of capacity that's got to lay in. And it's always been pretty indicative of kind of the level that the industrial machine is working at because a lot of it is one-for-one replacement. And I think -- I mean, all of our plants are working pretty fast, and I suspect that's the case out in a lot of the places we supply to. So that's holding up well.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Eric Ashleman", "section_number": 11, "uuid": "618841a6-269a-4f0d-8e1e-a0bc728a6955", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and President at IDEX"}

section.text: And one last one just on your own inventory levels. Obviously, everybody has been carrying a bit of extra inventory through these disrupted times. Plans on where you think that goes to in 2023? And what kind of cash generation we should be looking at for next year?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Nathan Jones", "section_number": 12, "uuid": "239f87a9-0ecc-4452-91d4-1bbf243d6237", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Stifel"}

section.text: Yes. The third quarter was the first time in the last several that we actually didn't build incremental inventory. And we've stabilized the recurring levels and look to bleed here in the fourth quarter, progressing into the first half of next year. Obviously, we said our long-term goal is to be at over 100% cash flow conversion. And I think we'll progress to that level over the next couple of quarters. First half is always a little bit light from a cash flow perspective on timing, and we're more back half loaded. But we look to continue to progress our inventory balances down here over the next six months.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Eric Ashleman", "section_number": 13, "uuid": "0506c2a3-e2d3-4dd3-8db1-0896d77a13b6", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and President at IDEX"}

section.text: Thank you very much for taking my question.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Nathan Jones", "section_number": 14, "uuid": "3de516f4-149c-496d-84b1-5093eab6d2d5", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Stifel"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Eric Ashleman", "section_number": 15, "uuid": "8cce58fd-589f-4cb1-81bf-19b5a0cbb063", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and President at IDEX"}

section.text: Thank you, good morning everyone. I'd like to follow up on Nathan's last question there for Bill. Is there any way to quantify the inventory that you're carrying that would be considered more buffer inventory that as lead times begin to normalize, you can start to sell that down. And then Eric just talked about being aggressive with the opportunity on some of the fast -- short-cycle businesses that the inventory ready to go. So that's kind of -- would be offsetting to that. But can you quantify for us what that opportunity would be to normalize working capital?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Deane Dray", "section_number": 17, "uuid": "56d2ac47-0aa6-4384-b513-2b4d664f65fb", "speaker_title": "Analyst at RBC Capital Markets"}

section.text: I think internally, we're targeting to get somewhere between 0.5 turn and a turn as we progress to our more historic levels. The buffer inventory is probably at the lower end of that, that we'll keep some of that as the businesses look on the strategic side, where we've been able to take share with some of that inventory level, we'll keep that. And the focus is just as we've built up inventory to buffer and/or have had to increase inventory levels based upon quantities we had to commit to or customers that have paused some of their shipments as they worked out supply chain issues on their side, we've built up a little bit of finished goods. Those parts will be the first part to bleed. And the things that we think are strategic to enable some of the share capture, we'll hold on to that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "William Grogan", "section_number": 18, "uuid": "e396e033-705f-4012-af9e-d5aa8b27f0dc", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at IDEX"}

section.text: All right. Good. That's helpful. And then can we just go through at whatever level you'd like to share the whole cancellation of the customer COVID test application I think you frame for how it was -- how that came about and the impairment that you took. Is that the end of it in terms of as it been completely written off and you did include it in your operating results, which we appreciate.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Deane Dray", "section_number": 19, "uuid": "3b57ff75-5ac1-408b-b8b9-c39c7bfc6f2f", "speaker_title": "Analyst at RBC Capital Markets"}

section.text: Yes, that's the end of it. I mean there's some small shipments here in the fourth quarter. But fundamentally, it was an initiative that we started and highlighted back in 2020. We partnered with that customer and had a great relationship relative to the partnership on developing the technology and then committing a significant amount of capital to support our production capabilities. And obviously, as they've moved in a different direction have got out of the testing caused the impairment and then the recognition of all the deferred revenue here within the quarter. So most of the noise is -- have been taken here in the third quarter, we've kind of moved past with significant knowledge gained in terms of production capabilities and technology that we'll continue to leverage as we move forward.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "William Grogan", "section_number": 20, "uuid": "9a1d13c0-7ddb-4d51-8d93-f2e9614f5c31", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at IDEX"}

section.text: That's really helpful. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Deane Dray", "section_number": 21, "uuid": "3a096dff-7cf9-49f9-ad84-7288fa64fdd4", "speaker_title": "Analyst at RBC Capital Markets"}

section.text: Sure.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "William Grogan", "section_number": 22, "uuid": "f048741d-a7a4-4fae-b883-93e295426a2e", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at IDEX"}

section.text: Hi, good morning. Yes, a little more color on the decision to align FSD and FMT under one leader. Does it indicate sort of maybe potentially more divestitures as you kind of look to refine the portfolio going forward? Just any thoughts there.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Allison Poliniak", "section_number": 24, "uuid": "31254aa7-99e4-449a-b1c5-f2efcb98a600", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wells Fargo"}

section.text: No, I appreciate the question. What I was really trying to emphasize in the remarks is we were looking for a leader with frankly, experience, scale and depth of experiences and the broad reach which would line up well with where we want to go as a company. And so that by sort of combining those businesses at least under her watch, it allows us to essentially position the skill, attract somebody of that caliber and put somebody on the team -- it's honestly got some experience in some of the areas where we want to go. It's completely about that. Everything else underneath Melissa is identical to what we've seen before. We kept it very separate and distinct. We run it exactly the same, but it allows one person to come on to the team with some very, very good capabilities.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Eric Ashleman", "section_number": 25, "uuid": "10f59dd0-3581-48d8-998a-51bca99a1917", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and President at IDEX"}

section.text: Great. And then, Bill, just going back to the HST orders, I think you kind of alluded to the fact that they were just -- there were some orders that were essentially just pushed into Q4. Have they been executed on? Have they turned into orders? Or is it something we're still leading to come forward here?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Allison Poliniak", "section_number": 26, "uuid": "1ab0ba65-eee8-4c84-86a8-9efabdf21788", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wells Fargo"}

section.text: Yes. No, not yet. The teams are still negotiating final pricing for things going into next year. So if we get them in Q4, first part of Q1, we'll get them, it's just a matter of time.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "William Grogan", "section_number": 27, "uuid": "52a6d8e9-e70e-4fab-8667-bfea05fa524d", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at IDEX"}

section.text: Great, thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Allison Poliniak", "section_number": 28, "uuid": "b08bc1ea-3635-494d-9a77-88f9b44fabdf", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wells Fargo"}

section.text: Hi, good morning all. I was hoping you might be able to parse out how you're thinking about accretion this year and next on a carryover basis for the two recent acquisitions in Muon and KZ.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Brett Linzey", "section_number": 30, "uuid": "33822e41-618d-4749-b027-4de02f4ebe49", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Mizuho"}

section.text: In terms of incremental EPS?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "William Grogan", "section_number": 31, "uuid": "b04637ad-7b67-4f72-9f79-601cf39b10c2", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at IDEX"}

section.text: Yes. So EPS accretion baked into the guide for this year and then what you're thinking about for next year carryover?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Brett Linzey", "section_number": 32, "uuid": "219f11a3-e8d1-44ad-842f-3abba18259ec", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Mizuho"}

section.text: You know this year, just a couple of cents here in the back half -- and then we'll have a couple of cents there in the first half of next year as it will comp as we progress into Q3 and Q4.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "William Grogan", "section_number": 33, "uuid": "43180c3a-08b1-45d9-996f-b90373773a93", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at IDEX"}

section.text: Okay. Great. And then I was hoping maybe you could just give a little bit of color on the regional dynamic within orders. And then specifically, what the pace of that looks like through the quarter on a monthly basis and what you're seeing in October in Europe specifically.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Brett Linzey", "section_number": 34, "uuid": "3464d1d2-9608-4578-bd77-04c8a6a8b48c", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Mizuho"}

section.text: I'm sorry, Greg, the cadence of orders within each month in the third quarter?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "William Grogan", "section_number": 35, "uuid": "f37caf7b-04cd-41fa-ba75-17448b96200a", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at IDEX"}

section.text: Yes, I was thinking more on a regional basis, what the cadence of monthly orders was and how that progressed into October as well by the different regions?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Brett Linzey", "section_number": 36, "uuid": "2b9b9ee3-f77e-459a-a2f4-4765e3df9978", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Mizuho"}

section.text: I would say the third quarter has got some seasonality and historically relative to European holidays and slowness within August, relative to normal order patterns, there weren't anything that was a significant outlier relative to what we've seen over the years. As Eric talked about, fundamental orders in our book and ship businesses were strong throughout the quarter. They continue to be strong here in October. Most of the softness, like we said, a little bit on the book and ship stuff in Europe and then some of the project-related business and some of the ordering was probably the bigger item within our European geographical look. North America and Asia still remain really, really strong.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "William Grogan", "section_number": 37, "uuid": "755073fa-0814-40ce-89d7-8656d8fe715e", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at IDEX"}

section.text: And October, pretty consistent with what we saw in Q3.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Eric Ashleman", "section_number": 38, "uuid": "f71feab4-fd64-403d-a29c-115fa8408ef7", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and President at IDEX"}

section.text: Okay. Great. I will let it pass along.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Brett Linzey", "section_number": 39, "uuid": "effecda5-ba57-4e38-a1bc-8effbbbdafa2", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Mizuho"}

section.text: Hi, thanks. Congratulations on the strong quarter. I just had a question on kind of near-term results here specific to the HST business you provided some pretty helpful commentary for us on some of those main drivers, the lower productivity and some of the discretionary investments that offset volume and improving price cost from a margin standpoint in Q3. So it would be helpful if there is any way that you could kind of quantify how that impacted EBIT margins on a sequential basis? Just trying to think through the evolution from Q2 to Q3 from those headwinds? And maybe how you see that progressing moving through the remainder of the year.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Thomas Johnson", "section_number": 41, "uuid": "3ea3c2eb-75bc-47ab-85b5-09992cee1de0", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morgan Stanley"}

section.text: Yes. I'd probably highlight to some of the productivity challenges as we ramped on some of the higher tech stuff in a couple of businesses within HST. Yes, sequentially, it was down versus the second quarter. We think it will ramp back up here as the business continues to progress and normalize and get more efficient in several of the facilities that we'll see a pickup in the fourth quarter.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "William Grogan", "section_number": 42, "uuid": "1e34ac65-9a37-412a-8f09-18bdd20fedc6", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at IDEX"}

section.text: Great, thanks. That is all for me.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Thomas Johnson", "section_number": 43, "uuid": "5f3152bf-35ef-4005-bd7e-2bc8636c29c3", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morgan Stanley"}

section.text: Morning guys, thanks for taking my call. Okay. So -- can you just talk about -- you've obviously talked throughout the recovery about taking some share given your ability to service customers and your availability. So as we're starting to see supply chain constraints gradually ease, can you talk about how you expect share trends to evolve as some of your competitors who were maybe more hamstrung at times are coming back more online to normalized service levels?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Vlad Bystricky", "section_number": 45, "uuid": "eff87912-25ea-4b7e-a21b-a21626dae673", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citigroup"}

section.text: Sure. Well, there's probably two elements there I want to cover. There's one that I would argue we kind of carry most days. We generally have shorter lead times than a lot of the people we compete against when things are in normal state. I mean, we engineered the businesses to run that way, and it's kind of all set up there. What's actually happened for us here with a lot of the share capture over the last couple of quarters, so we made some really sharp calls on some inventory that's pretty specific, highly technical and not in wide supply. We see some things coming the businesses to their credit without frankly, approval loops and things that we don't need in a company like ours. They said, "Hey, we know how critical this is. We can kind of see where it's going to go. We're going to lay some in." And so almost all of the share capture that we talk about, you can kind of take it right back into very specialized material that we accumulated.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Eric Ashleman", "section_number": 46, "uuid": "0583ea10-1c61-409d-ab03-be3c3336ae6f", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and President at IDEX"}

section.text: So I think that's important because otherwise, you might just think it's very benign stuff and metal bits and brackets and things like that where we just have to have them laying around. That actually would normalize as things improve. This is actually very, very strategic inventory that these businesses accumulated. So that's an advantage state out of the gate. That's what we're largely referring to here. But then as we go when things normalize, we normalize and maintain that advantage, the natural advantage we have in many of our businesses. So it's just an area that we always emphasize. It's kind of been dramatically positive for us because of really, really good choices in businesses.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Eric Ashleman", "section_number": 46, "uuid": "0583ea10-1c61-409d-ab03-be3c3336ae6f", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and President at IDEX"}

section.text: Okay. That's really helpful color. And then maybe just as we think about organic sales, obviously, you've surprised to the upside here over the past couple of quarters and just raised your 22% organic growth outlook. So can you just maybe parse out a little more what's driving that better top line growth? How much of it is incremental better pricing than you expected versus just better volume-driven growth?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Vlad Bystricky", "section_number": 47, "uuid": "7e0a9d69-3731-425d-a226-418d67ca43ee", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citigroup"}

section.text: Well, yes, I mean it's -- there are certainly components of outperformance that are here. So I'm glad that you're bringing that up. I mean our pricing is the highest level we've had out throughout the year. We've been pushing that continuously. This is the kind of environment where our differentiated products are going to command the highest level of pricing. So that is no doubt a component, and that's competitively advantaged. We talk a lot about the top bets in the company, the top best growth bets. They're the highest quality we've had. And so interspersed in all of the numbers that we're talking about, you see great things like broadband and outer space and things we're doing in genomics and some of the things going on in water and Precision Ag and through FMT and now some acceleration that we've been waiting for and the fire businesses in FSD. So those bets are layered in with higher unit of measures than we've seen historically on top of recovering markets and well-positioned businesses. That's kind of the entitlement that we have really strong price capture and a great stack up of that's across the company.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Eric Ashleman", "section_number": 48, "uuid": "589a67b9-5afc-4268-aae6-c9d98aac909e", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and President at IDEX"}

section.text: That is helpful, great color. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Vlad Bystricky", "section_number": 49, "uuid": "f1f58c3e-0531-4c81-be94-3449034b7431", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citigroup"}

section.text: Good morning everyone. so I just have a general question. I wonder if you might tell the, I guess, the story of Muon Group acquisition and how it shows by the new process, multiples and other opportunities you have, whether it soaks up a lot of availability or whether you're still active. Just kind of walk through how -- obviously, you've had pretty strong success in acquisitions lately, and that's been a focus. I'd just like to get color on how that transpired?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Rob Wertheimer", "section_number": 51, "uuid": "11413c69-486c-4fb0-97e4-882bb46ce339", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Melius Research"}

section.text: Yes. Well, it's a business we've known for a few years. It's very much an IDEX business. I mean it's a highly precise niche component doing wonderful jobs for a variety of high-end markets including the ones that we had identified in the prepared remarks. I give a lot of credit to Marc Uleman, who I referenced in my opening remarks, it's a Netherlands-based business. Marc is located in the Netherlands, and he kept a very active cadence with his team over the last few years. We found a time in a space where we were able to generate some actionability. And got the deal done mainly because we could get our head around it very, very quickly based on the work we've done over the last few years and our familiarity with it. What's great about a business like this one is -- and the reason I say it's so IDEX-like as it's actually very tunable.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Eric Ashleman", "section_number": 52, "uuid": "8f7fd7c2-3931-4e52-80d8-78a62a5fb481", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and President at IDEX"}

section.text: That's one of the reasons we like these precise components businesses. So it pings into some very high-quality areas of semi con there's some great applications in medical devices, food production, high-end food production, all areas that we study and participate in across the business, so we can leverage that insight and then apply it on a high-quality niche business like this one. Longer-term down the road, this actually sits next to a lot of things we have in our scientific fluidic and optic spaces. So there's some commercial relationships that we could leverage there. There's actually some very interesting technical questions and things that we're going to explore together over a longer duration. And then honestly, and we think of value creation, we just start to fly the way we run things at IDEX.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Eric Ashleman", "section_number": 52, "uuid": "8f7fd7c2-3931-4e52-80d8-78a62a5fb481", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and President at IDEX"}

section.text: You can take a high-quality business like that, we would start with 80/20. It's not all applications are created equal. We have a way of thinking about that, that we can teach to others -- things like value capture with customers, and we do that really well. And so there's a whole bunch of leverageable assets as well. Just that you apply against an already very, very strong business that's got a demonstrated history of growth. So I think we're really, really excited about it. I think it's indicative of the kind of things that we're looking at and looking for. And yes. We'll see -- we'll certainly talk to you about it as we go.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Eric Ashleman", "section_number": 52, "uuid": "8f7fd7c2-3931-4e52-80d8-78a62a5fb481", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and President at IDEX"}

section.text: And then Rob, to your capacity comment, I mean after the completion of Muon, we'll have spent about $1.5 billion over the last two years with really taking on a minimal amount of incremental leverage -- so we'll have $1.5 billion to spend here over the next 12 months with a robust funnel and a lot of actionable assets within that funnel.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "William Grogan", "section_number": 53, "uuid": "2f7f4a7d-fb4a-4ba5-9a87-7dc332046638", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at IDEX"}

section.text: No, that was a comprehensive answer. And any commentary on whether that's an abnormally large asset within your funnel or whether it's paper to or big and small? And with that, I will stop.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Rob Wertheimer", "section_number": 54, "uuid": "485b8cb7-28ce-4b8d-be20-ad738c55df9f", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Melius Research"}

section.text: Yes. No, I mean, it's a little larger than we've seen before. But I mean, the nature of these kind of high-quality niches, they tend to be in very similar spaces. And the kind of the top end of the size of them is actually relatively constant across even the wide variety of businesses that we have. So a well-positioned business that's closer to the top end in a high-quality niche like we think about is often this size. So it's a little higher than we've seen before, but there's certainly more of them like it out there.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Eric Ashleman", "section_number": 55, "uuid": "82822030-13d9-48c4-89fb-c8f9eaa4b298", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and President at IDEX"}

section.text: Okay, thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Rob Wertheimer", "section_number": 56, "uuid": "aae9b1c9-b1b8-4f9b-ae92-5c1ef2839bc9", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Melius Research"}

section.text: Thanks, just a couple of quick ones here. With FSD, how far behind is that business in terms of price/cost, meaning how much more margin can we look forward to as you fully close that gap? And then sticking with that business, on the dispensing side, how much of a revenue hole should we expect in 2023 from those big projects that revenue this year? And then I have one follow-up.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matt Summerville", "section_number": 58, "uuid": "cadd1e3c-c5dc-4f94-82db-5cf7973cdb52", "speaker_title": "Analyst at D.A. Davidson"}

section.text: Sure. I think we look for FSD to continue its ramp. We had said last quarter, it had bottomed out and will continue to progress as we move forward. With the caveat that we still need to assess the project funnel for next year for dispensing. Right now, we don't think there's a huge hole. There will be some softness on the replenishment side, if we weren't able to fill some of those larger projects that would put a little bit of pressure on FSD's margins relative to the progress that Fire & Rescue has made. So right now, we're still evaluating the impact of what the project funnel is for dispensing and obviously give you more detail here as we get into the guide in January.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "William Grogan", "section_number": 59, "uuid": "4e15a1f2-c721-40ad-a2ee-2f7ecfaf9466", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at IDEX"}

section.text: And then just a modeling question, the divestiture that Knight divestiture, can you disclose the financial profile of that business?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matt Summerville", "section_number": 60, "uuid": "55788b74-a265-459f-896b-0f20e999f972", "speaker_title": "Analyst at D.A. Davidson"}

section.text: Yes. I mean it was less than 1% of revenue and obviously a nonmaterial amount of profit for us.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "William Grogan", "section_number": 61, "uuid": "cdd9a9f4-d992-465c-97fe-60cbb80339eb", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at IDEX"}

section.text: Got it, that is all for me. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Matt Summerville", "section_number": 62, "uuid": "9e01a63a-46f9-44da-aa3f-3160fdea6ae0", "speaker_title": "Analyst at D.A. Davidson"}

section.text: Hi, good morning everyone. Congratulations on another standout quarter. I have questions, just sort of a broad-based question on organic first. With the supply chain improving a little bit, several quarters ago, Eric, you were able to take your best guess at quantifying what the negative was. With the improvement in the chain, can you maybe quantify what the positive was on organic this quarter?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Scott Graham", "section_number": 64, "uuid": "007f1fdc-69ef-4888-8050-12bb48d66f30", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Loop Capital Markets"}

section.text: I mean from a share capture and things we're able to do. I mean...
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Eric Ashleman", "section_number": 65, "uuid": "37fb9c8f-298c-4011-b536-238aa25ef6b4", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and President at IDEX"}

section.text: Well, actually trying to maybe -- if share capture is part of it, sure, but kind of more like backlog depletion things getting out that was hung up in backlog that maybe you didn't expect. But I'm assuming that there was a bit additive to organic from a better chain?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Scott Graham", "section_number": 66, "uuid": "6b2dae9a-a761-4ea9-be31-1ea9675b7d29", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Loop Capital Markets"}

section.text: I think it's a small amount, Scott. I think we've stabilized relative to our production output levels as you look at where we've been from a revenue perspective. It's slightly elevated. So a point or two at most. We've burned a little bit of backlog within the quarter, but backlog position is still pretty high. It was a pretty minor burn there.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "William Grogan", "section_number": 67, "uuid": "eabeac03-c393-4bfa-afe4-393873dd4bae", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at IDEX"}

section.text: Got you. Okay. Great. That was helpful. also, and I hope this doesn't count as a follow-up. What was pricing -- I didn't hear it if you said it?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Scott Graham", "section_number": 68, "uuid": "e172314f-6c5b-4a6b-ac19-3e7702cab636", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Loop Capital Markets"}

section.text: No, no. We didn't. So second quarter, we were at 4%. We ramped here in the third, a little over 5%.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "William Grogan", "section_number": 69, "uuid": "31d0b1a8-2e1a-4cfe-9416-b518a847cbe0", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at IDEX"}

section.text: Okay, thank you. And then just a question about the water business. It's a pretty big business. You called it out as certainly an area of strength. And -- can you kind of talk about the dynamics of the growth in the quarter? And is that a market that maybe would be a clear sort of green shoot market for you next year as well?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Scott Graham", "section_number": 70, "uuid": "d2d26d60-99af-47b9-a594-98c90146aeee", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Loop Capital Markets"}

section.text: I mean it's a good market. I always remind people that the work that we do there is on the analytical side of supporting whether the infrastructure's ability to work well. So that kind of work. I mean it maps well with a lot of the digital solutions that are out there. That's where some of our more digital businesses are. So robo crawlers and flow monitoring to prevent overflows and things that could harm the environment. That's the work that we're doing. The bulk of it, of course, made an acquisition to deepen that here recently. So you've got some very good assets that we think long-term, obviously, there's no question the work needs to be done.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Eric Ashleman", "section_number": 71, "uuid": "127a66d7-7c7f-448f-b9ce-895594de4fa0", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and President at IDEX"}

section.text: It's long overdue. There's a decent amount of stimulus and government support that's out there that always takes longer to find its way into projects than people imagine. But that frankly extends it over multiple years, too. So it's just -- we kind of put that in a positive side. I'd agree on the green shoot side of it. We're very, very well-positioned. We're doing -- continuing integration work with the acquisition that we have to deepen all of it in our major geographies, and we view it as very favorable.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Eric Ashleman", "section_number": 71, "uuid": "127a66d7-7c7f-448f-b9ce-895594de4fa0", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and President at IDEX"}

section.text: Got it, thanks again.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Scott Graham", "section_number": 72, "uuid": "b2eea6c3-54dd-4f4d-b57c-12962135e9ff", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Loop Capital Markets"}

section.text: Good morning this is Michael on for Joe. In the prepared remarks, you mentioned strength around energy. Can you just dive a bit into the LNG outlook for FMT? And if there's any future alternative energy opportunities? I know historically, -- that's been an area of inorganic growth.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael", "section_number": 74, "uuid": "56f9d7a7-f402-4b03-9c74-c37246a03be7", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Cowen"}

section.text: Yes. Well, I mean, I think our energy businesses have recovered pretty nicely throughout the year. I mean, we've seen a few -- we don't have a ton of upstream presence, but that's been stronger here lately. I think the midstream has got some delays and things on the project side and supply chain, some of the classic stuff, but probably lines up behind it because there are some things that are overdue there. And we've got -- I mean, we've got kind of a classic custody transfer business, a lot of it fossil fuel dependent with the current assets.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Eric Ashleman", "section_number": 75, "uuid": "7258234e-4aee-40b7-b016-e755f0409270", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and President at IDEX"}

section.text: On that technology, we're actually asking all the questions, as you might imagine, of how transferable it is to other alternate energy sources and things that might be out there. Whatever it is, whether it's hydrogen or some other gases and liquids it's going to need -- people are going to need to get paid and we're going to need to measure that custody transfer happens. And that's kind of work that we long have done and are excited about. There are actually other areas of IDEX that map against some of those same vectors in a way that is probably what strike folks on the outside is kind of unusual as well. That's one of the ways we think of a trend like that is we kind of draw lines and tentacles into different verticals within IDEX. And then we sort of leverage insight around how the work is done, how things are shaping up.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Eric Ashleman", "section_number": 75, "uuid": "7258234e-4aee-40b7-b016-e755f0409270", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and President at IDEX"}

section.text: And then distribute it across a variety of IDEX businesses that might be involved. They may not be going to market together, they might not even be in the same room, but actually some of the same dynamics are meaningful for them in terms of why they would want to invest in it. So it's an area of interest for us in terms of how this will ultimately play out over time. But I think for now, the kind of core things that we have are doing pretty well with a decent road and runway ahead.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Eric Ashleman", "section_number": 75, "uuid": "7258234e-4aee-40b7-b016-e755f0409270", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and President at IDEX"}

section.text: Thanks that's helpful. And just one follow-up, if I may. Are there any product adjacencies that within the energy sphere that you see more favorable? And if this is something that's sort of in the funnel for over the next 12 months or so?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael", "section_number": 76, "uuid": "39a810d3-a8fe-4061-afa6-eb8206779791", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Cowen"}

section.text: I mean we've got some great projects there. They, as you might imagine, go very, very niche, very, very quickly. As an example, we've got a great application that make sure that when you offload a railcar with propane, you get all of it out of the bottom. I mean it seems kind of funny. You did suspect everybody would suspect that actually happens, it doesn't. So our team developed something that guarantees that 100% of the fuel is taken out of the car, and then that's available as productivity for a variety of people. So it's that kind of work, that's sort of -- that's the unit a measure of things we think about and develop for customers. And there are others along the way, but that's just when we happened to take a look at about a month ago. It's really, really interesting.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Eric Ashleman", "section_number": 77, "uuid": "51627d53-d0b2-47ba-9e78-5dadb63fdc70", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and President at IDEX"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael", "section_number": 78, "uuid": "5e1237da-27c4-422e-a9d5-94d0f42db869", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Cowen"}

section.text: Well, thanks. I appreciate the comments and the reflection on what we think was a very strong quarter here. For any of the IDEX team members that are listening, I want to thank you all again, personally for your hard work, certainly difficult circumstances, a lot of change happening quarter-over-quarter, month-over-month. But as I said in the end of my remarks, this is a company where we really lean into that. Any time the world gets difficult, they're problems worth solving. And when they -- and when we solve them with well-positioned businesses, I mean, it's a huge financial benefit for ourselves and our shareholders. So thanks for your interest. Look forward to talking to you more along the way.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Eric Ashleman", "section_number": 80, "uuid": "966b3c17-51fd-4cb4-a4fc-cb80954454e4", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and President at IDEX"}

title: Q&A for IEX (IDEX) on 10/26/22 10:30 AM ET
